org.hermann.media

Class Icons

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.hermann.media.Icons

  • public class Icons
extends java.lang.Object
    I'm not sure what's the best way to import the chess piece images into my project, but I think it's a good idea to create a separate class for them like Adrian did. I don't know if it's really necessary to declare the constructor private and make sure that there can only be one instance of Icons, but it won't do any harm...

    It might be actually a good idea because when we scale the icons to be the size of the JButtons in BoardSquares we make sure that we don't mix up images from two different instances of Icons and get some scaled and some unscaled images. But since we would only need one instance of Icons anyway, we could also make it an attribute of BoardSquares and just use it nowhere else, doesn't really matter I suppose.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Icons

        private Icons()
        In out constructor we just read in the image streams and put them into our attributes, we have to think about what to do if the images are not found, since a game without visible chess pieces on the board is pretty hard to play.

        Well, here's the thing: apparently it is not possible to set a BufferedImage as a background image or Icon in a JButton, we can only use ImageIcon objects as Icons using the .setIcon() method to get the picture into a JButton and since the entire visualization of the board is based on JButtons that's a problem.

        It would be possible to just read in the images in as icons, BUT apparently ImageIcons are not resizable, which leaves us with fixed sized pictures in a bunch of JButtons, which, on the other hand, have different height and width depending on the size of the screen. For a BufferedImage this wouldn't be a problem as there is a .getScaledInstace(int width, int height, int hints) method, that makes it easy to scale the picture.

        So I came up with a rather ugly solution as a last resort: First we get the pictures as BufferedImages then we resize them and finally "cast" them into an ImageIcon. I don't really see any other solution to this problem.

        NOTE: We don't need to scale the images with a specific factor, but only make sure that they fit into the JButtons in BoardSquares, I guess we'll just take the height of our BoardSquares and divide it by 8, so we'll have the height and width of a single button (it's a square so we only need the height)
